Description: Hollow terracotta figure of Isis enthroned, preparing to suckle Harpokrates. She wears her Isis-shawl with the fringed edges indicated, and bares her left breast to the child. Her hair is similar to that of the empress Julia Domna and is surmounted by a horned crown with feathers and disc, and ears of wheat. Her feet rest on a footstool with a twisted inclination like that of the 'Bryaxis' Sarapis. The back of the throne has incuse details of its construction. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt, with dark-brown surface. Traces of a white dressing on the front.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Acquired from Major Charles Kerr Macdonald, and found by him at Saqqara in 1849. Roman, about ad 200. Comparanda: Close, probably same mould-series: Dunand 1979: no. 4. Near: Christie’s New York Sale Catalogue, 18 December 1998: lot 138; Dunand 1990: no. 372 = Tran Tam Tinh 1973: pl. xxxix:62b; Tran Tam Tinh 1978: pl. ccxxi, dated first century ad; Török 1995: no. 107, dated not earlier than the Severan period and, although not very close, has the same angled footstool; Weber 1914: no. 38 (head only), from Theadelphia, and Weber 1914: 38, fig. 12. Bibliog: Fischer 1994: 342, no. 844.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3014)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2022 19 May – 25 Sept, London, British Museum, Feminine Power
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Maj Charles Kerr Macdonald
